While we are developing our app, we don’t want to set the user testing on hold. So we decided to test a digital prototype first.
The backbone of the app is still missing. We use dummy data just to be able to get users comments soon.
In the final version of the paper prototype. We had only very few, small issues so we decided to implement the solutions in the digital prototype immediately.

Goal:

Once the digital prototype was finished, we tested it keeping 3 focus points in mind:

  1. Did the translation form paper to digital prototype succeed?
  2. What do users think about the (small) adjustments we made.
  3. Is it clear that you can give an overall good rating, but yet add a negative point to that same review.

Here’s some extra explanation concerning those 3 focus points:

  1. We wanted to see weather the translation to a digital prototype brought any new issues. Even though the users were looking at almost exactly the same pages, there might be cases in which something is clear on paper, but isn’t in a digital environment.
  2. We made 3 adjustments:
    1. We adapted the rating visualizer once again. The solution of centering the split point between green and red (see blog post 15 march) made perfect sense to us when we drew it on paper. Implementing this solution in a digital environment immediately made clear this was not the case. The central outlining point just wasn’t clear on screen. The bars seemed to appear random on the screen even though they were centred well. We decided not to test is with users because the three of us all felt the same about this solution: rubbish! Our new solution is to make two bars: one for the positive comments and one for the negative comments.

      The bars for positive and negative ratings appear below each other.

    2. We also made a change to make the app more consistent. Since we focus on people in Leuven, we make our app in Dutch. In our paper prototype we printed the word “rate” on the button which has to be pushed to give an opinion on a frituur. But, obviously, this is an English word so we decided to print a Duch one: “Stem”.
    3. The last change is more of an omission: In our paper prototype we used tabs to make the difference between friends ratings and everyones ratings. We did not yet implement those tabs in the digital prototype so we just dropped this concept in this version of the test. Given the fact that there were no issues with those tabs in de paper prototype, we don’t expect users to have difficulties when we implement the tabs in the future.
  3. In our first tests, we didn’t give the user freedom in rating a frituur. We were happy when he found the rating page and rated a frituur. But the users was not able to fill in comments (we already filled it in). In this iteration, we are letting the user decide for himself what rating he gives a frituur. We want to see weather it is clear that you can give an overall good rating, but yet add a negative point to that same review.

Method:
To get user feedback we let them perform a specific task. We also used the think aloud technique. After the tasks are completed we ask the users about their experience, this could be seen as a questionaire.

Rationale:
We wanted to measure the effectiveness of our app. By letting the users perform tasks we can see weather he can complete those tasks. The think aloud part permits us to see how users look at the application and thus see if he uses things the way they are intended to be used. The questionnaire permits us to ask the user more global questions afterwards.

Who what when?
The tasks were performed by students computer science on an iPhone.

the tasks consisted of:
1) Search a frituur within 2km from where you are right now.
2) Filter the frituren so you only keep the ones with “poor” in their name
3) undo this filter
4) Select the best frituur that meets your criterium (2km)
5) What is the address of the frituur?
6)What do other people think about the frituur?
7) When was the last time someone gave a negative rating to this frituur
8) You ate at this frituur and want to rate it you had: Many fries for a good price, lovely hamburgers but very distasteful mayonnaise. Give the frituur a rating.

Results:

All users completed all tasks. That is a very good result we think! Most users liked the interface of our app. Which is always nice to hear. We will now go over all issues that surfaced, starting with the ones concerning the adaptations we made:

  1. Every users found the rating visualizer clear.
  2. There was one comment on the “Stem” button (during the questionnaire). For this user, “Stem” had an electoral connotation, so he assumed ‘stem’ immediately meant he would give is ‘vote’ to that frituur. We do not change this because the other users had no problems and also this user completed the rating task without problems. The user mentioned this issue during the questionnaire.

Other issues:

  1. An issue that returns with most users is the sorting of frituren in the result list. We now sort the list by distance (nearest first). Every users seems to get that, but they’d also like to see a sorting which takes the ratings into account. So we decided to add an advanced filter which allows users to get a list with the best frituur on top. To do this, users will have to give a max. distance (this to avoid that you are in Leuven and get info on a very good frituur in Oostende).
  2. Al lot of users had problems with the map that shows the frituur location. When you try to scroll in the profile page and hold your finger on the map to do so, you only scroll the map in stead of the whole profile page. We will thus try to make the initial map an image, which can be clicked for further detail, if that is possible.
  3. Another problem is that some users didn’t find the map very useful. But the map didn’t show the data we wanted it to show (it does not work properly yet). It just showed an overview of Leuven. Which is not very handy indeed. We will thus not take this comment into account at this point, but return to it when it displays the data we want, and still get the comment that it is not handy.

Conclusion:

We think the translation worked pretty well. The fact that we had one important new issue shows that this digital prototype testing was not a bad idea. When testing the paper prototype, users didn’t care that much about the sorting of the list. We assume it just feels unnatural to think that you can sort a paper list. Hence, users didn’t complain about it back then. But in a digital environment, we immediately expect that a list is customisable/sortable.

After reading a post of one of the other ChiKUL13-teams (they had the brilliant idea of creating a screen transition diagram of their app), we decided to make a quick diagram of our own showing the screen transitions of our current application-prototype:

Screens are visualized as rectangles, the other boxes are actions the user can do. Arrows denote which action leads to which screens. The start screen of the application is the ‘Login’-screen.

Goal of the iteration

Trying to discover the biggest problems with the user interface of our application and find solutions for these problems.

Method

  • Let the participant executing a couple of tasks and let him/her say what he/she thinks when executing that task
  • Let participants make proposals themselves about how they would like to see it done
  • Ask them about their general impressions and remarks after the test

Rationale

The think-aloud method was used in this iteration, because it goes well with testing a paper prototype. In this method the participant explains what he is thinking when executing a given task or seeing a certain screen. When?testing a paper prototype, it is most important to discover problems with the interface, not with the functionality, because there is not real functionality in this kind of prototype.

Who, what, where

  • Who: 6 students of this course, between 20 and 22 years old, good knowledge of existing technologies
  • Where: in the room where the sessions of the course are given
  • What (tasks): logging in, making suggestions, opening the details of a suggestions, like a suggestion, searching
  • Duration: between 5 and 10 minutes for each participant

Results

  1. In the explore-screen there are toggle-buttons to indicate in which categories the user wants to seek. 3 participants didn’t perceive this functionality of the toggle-buttons.
  2. 4 participants only found the explore-tab, because it was the only tab in the navigation bar that wasn’t used yet.
  3. 1 participants asked us why the navigation bar was at the bottom of the screen.
  4. Based on a like or dislike a suggestion was colored respectively green or red. 2 participants didn’t get the meaning of these colors. They also liked the idea of a like/dislike button in the main screen more, instead of first opening the details and then liking/disliking.
  5. All participants understood what was displayed in the To Me- and To Others-screen.
  6. Adding a photo to a new suggestion was also immediately clear to all participants.
  7. 2 participants only noticed that the application is meant to recommend locations when the added a new suggestion themselves.

Conclusion

  • Some participants didn’t get that the application should be used to recommend locations.
  • The toggle-buttons in the explore-screen aren’t immediately clear to some participants.
  • The color-rating of suggestions doesn’t speak for itself.
  • To Me- and To Others-screen is clear.
  • It speaks for itself how photos should be added to a new suggestion.
  • Not all participants think it’s logical to open a suggestion first and then like or dislike it.
  • The function of the explore-tab isn’t clear when the participant uses the application for the first time.

Goals when designing the first digital prototype

Here is a little recap of the problems we discovered when testing the paper prototype of our application:

  1. Indistinctness that the application should be used to recommend locations.
  2. Function of the toggle-buttons in the explore-screen not obvious.
  3. Color-rating of suggestions not clear.
  4. Not all users find it logical that a suggestion should be opened before they can like or dislike it.
  5. The functionality of the explore-tab isn’t clear when the user uses the application for the first time.

Possible solutions for these problemS

1. Login-screen

  • Mention on the login-screen that the application revolves around recommend locations and also reflect this in the name of the application.
  • Show some text that explains the application at start-up.

2. Toggle-buttons in the explore-screen

  • This problem is mostly owed to the fact that we used a paper prototype in our tests. In a digital prototype this would be clearer.
  • Making the different search domains disjoint, which would allows us to use a different selection mechanism (e.g. a dropdown menu).

3. Color-rating of suggestions

  • Keep this coloring and add an icon that indicates a like or a dislike.
  • Just show the icon for a like of a dislike.

4. Like/dislike-problem on the main-screen

  • Because only a few users indicated this, we could stick to the idea of first opening the details of a suggestion before liking or disliking.
  • Adding a like/dislike button in the main screen.

5. The functionality of the different tabs in the navigation bar

  • Choose names that reflect the functionality more
  • Adding icons to the different tabs
  • Substitute the names by icons.

Choosing a solution for each problem

  1. We choose the name ‘Xplorer’ and the slogan ‘Recommend the places you love’ to indicate to the user that our application should be used to recommend locations. This is better than showing some text at start-up, because this slows down the user when he wants to use the app and we don’t want to force the user to read that text before using the application.
  2. We made the search domains disjoint by using a selection menu instead of toggle-buttons.
  3. We replaced the color-rating by an icon on the main screen, which is also better for the color blind. This gives us also more opportunities for the color scheme of the applications, because we don’t have to take the green and red into account anymore.
  4. For now, we only keep a like and dislike button in the details of a suggestions, because only a few users reported this as a problem. If this still is a problem later on, it’s easy to add another button to the main screen.
  5. We added icons to the tabs and kept the names. By doing this the user is shown in two different ways what every tab stands for (e.g. a magnifying glass on the explore-tab).

In this post we will give a short overview of the first iteration of the development of our application Tip-It!

Iteration 1:

Goal

Get a general idea of the impression of the users. Do they understand and find the functionalities?

Method

We use the Wizard Paper Prototyping method together with the Think Aloud protocol.

Rationale

  • Wizard prototyping is highly applicable in our case because you can test en maybe adjust your prototype immediately. Different functionalities can easily be added or removed.
  • Think Aloud allows us to look into the mind of the users and to collect their thoughts.

Who, What, Where, Time?

  • Who? 4 co-students, each belonging to a different group from the class User Interfaces.?
  • What? In the first two tests, the users had to tell what they should do with the given prototype, without any information. What did they expect to happen when they executed their actions? The other two testpersons were asked to try some basic functionalities, namely give and like a tip.
  • Where? The tests took place at the campus in the 200B building.
  • Time? The duration of each test was 5 to 10 minutes.

Results

3 of the 4 people spontaneously told us that they liked the concept of the application! Yet there were some remarks:

  • R1.1:?The 4 testpersons all thought that the logo at the top of the site was a button. They also mentioned that it distracted them from the actual functionality.
  • R1.2: 2 users wondered if there was a friends-functionality en warned us for possible spam if the application was open to everybody.
  • R1.3:?One user asked if the possibility to send a tip to multiple persons exists.

Conclusion

  • In general the users were very enthusiastic about the application.
  • But a certain friends-functionality was clearly missed and will be included in the next iteration, just as the?possibility to send a tip to multiple persons (R1.2, R1.3).
  • The previews will include a link to?the site they represent (R1.4).

  • Notifications are not being handled in the next iteration, because this isn’t a basic functionality. Later on, we will elaborate this more (R1.5).

Easter break is over, beside some snow fun (instead of sunny days) we also worked on our CHIKul project. However this post will not be about an interface iteration, but about the backend of our project.

Our first idea was to work with Twitter. This has several major advantages:

  • Twitter has a large user base
  • Twitter has valuable information about a user which we can use
  • We can expect specific knowlegde and behavior from users: use hasthags, follow people, retweet, use short messages, …
  • Twitter has a storage engine which we can use to present the data that has been generated by our application
  • Twitter has a secure way of maintaining user information like names and passwords and you can connect to it with OAuth

Although all of these advantages should be true, we did experience two difficulties. First of all, the login with Tiggzi did not work. We did not succeed in getting the necessary tokens and keys to allow control of Twitter in our application (send tweets, follow people, … ).
Another very important disadvantage was that the search api of Twitter only returns tweets of the last 6 to 9 days. We could accept this if we focus more on events instead of recommendations in general. But the search api also mentioned that it did not give all of the tweets that match your criteria and were posted in the last days. It will only give top tweets and you have no control about this.

For us, those two advantages were too much. Because Tiggzi also provides a back end database as service and because we have enough knowlegde of databases we decided to maintain our own database.

We kept it very simple with only 2 entities: a user and a message; and 3 relations: follows, recommends and likes. You can see the picture of the database model here:

For our project, we intent to have users sign in with a 3rd party service. For now we have planned to implement Twitter, Google Accounts and Facebook login. It is very unlikely for a potential user not to have at least an account on one of these services. In this post I’ll talk about the difficulties we encountered when implementing ‘Sign in with Twitter’. We don’t have Google Accounts or Facebook login implemented yet, but looking at the API references for the three services it seems Twitter is the most complicated. This is probably because (unlike the other two) they use OAuth 1.0a, rather than OAuth 2.0. Before we get started, I’d like to point out that doing a manual implementation can be a time-consuming and slightly masochistic thing, so only do it if you like this kind of thing. Especially since there are plenty of people who have done it for you.

I won’t explain how to implement ‘Sign in with Twitter’, because Twitter already has a very good guide up for this. Instead I’ll be going over some small but hard to debug problems that may drive you crazy and possibly even make you give up if you can’t find them. In retrospect, the whole thing wasn’t actually all that complicated, it’s just somewhat hard to pin down the exact problem if it’s not working.

HTTP headers

When you’re debugging, make sure you can see all the headers of the HTTP requests you make and the replies you receive from Twitter’s servers. More information is always better, and headers that you may not have directly set can still cause problems.

In our case, cURL was setting the Content-length header to a default value of -1 (it should have been 0 for a request without POST parameters), causing us to get a HTTP 400 Bad Request. Because I wasn’t watching my headers I thought our OAuth implementation made an error somewhere and spent a lot of time looking for an error that wasn’t there.

Percent-encoding

Sending authorized requests to the Twitter API requires you to regularly percent-encode some values. Doing it one time too many or too few causes your request signature to be wrong and then your request won’t go through.

Signature parameters

API requests using OAuth need to have a correct signature based on what you put in your request. Double-check whether you have put all parameters in your signature: GET, POST and OAuth parameters should all be in there, and need to be sorted lexicographically (as the Twitter Dev pages note: this is usually the default alphabetical sorting for most libraries).

Example request

There are of course a whole lot of bugs that can pop up, and the best way to find them is to have a reference value. The ‘Sign in with Twitter’-guide is one example (the consumer secret they used to sign the request is at the top of the page), and here we give you another one:

Input values:

  • url = https://api.twitter.com/oauth/request_token
  • oauth_consumer_key = fakeconsumerkey
  • oauth_timestamp = 123456789
  • oauth_version = 1.0
  • oauth_signature_method = HMAC-SHA1
  • oauth_nonce = randomalphanumericstring
  • oauth_callback = http://anyurl.goes/even/localhost

Input to signing algorithm

POST&https%3A%2F%2Fapi.twitter.com%2Foauth%2Frequest_token&oauth_callback%3Dhttp%253A%252F%252Fanyurl.goes%252Feven%252Flocalhost%26oauth_consumer_key%3Dfakeconsumerkey%26oauth_nonce%3Drandomalphanumericstring%26oauth_signature_method%3DHMAC-SHA1%26oauth_timestamp%3D123456789%26oauth_version%3D1.0

Resulting request

POST /oauth/request_token HTTP/1.1 Host: api.twitter.com Accept: */* Authorization: OAuth oauth_callback="http%3A%2F%2Fanyurl.goes%2Feven%2Flocalhost", oauth_consumer_key="fakeconsumerkey", oauth_nonce="randomalphanumericstring", oauth_signature_method="HMAC-SHA1", oauth_timestamp="123456789", oauth_version="1.0", oauth_signature="4C5rk3aVpSsytkYbfDz2DZfcbZA%3D" Content-length: 0 Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded Expect: 100-continue

I hope this post can be of help to anyone wishing to implement the sign in procedure manually. If you have any remarks or questions, post them in the comments and we’ll try our best to help you out.

Goal of thE iteration

  • Testing whether the problems related to the paper prototype are solved
  • Analyzing the problems that come up now that are related to the digital prototype

Method

  • Let the user execute the exact same task we let him execute in the first iteration to see whether old problems are solved and new ‘digital’ problem arise
  • Let the user express his thoughts on every action
  • Afterwards ask the user for general impressions and/or problems
  • Count the number of clicks a user needs to execute every task
  • Timing the execution of each task

Rationale

  • Efficiency-test (counting the number of clicks) together with the think-aloud method. This way we can analyze clearly why a user does a certain click and possibly also why he does a wrong click.
  • Efficiency-test (timing every task) where the user concentrates only on the task we give him without telling us anything. This would be a good indicator of how fast our app lets users do what they want. But because our app has problems with loading times and we also only did this test on two people, we won’t mention the results here, because these results would be too specific.

Who, what, where

  • Who: 9 younger people between 20 and 24 years old (all smartphone users and students), 1 older person (50+, less experience with the use of applications)
  • What: opening the about-page, logging in, opening details of a suggestion, liking a suggestion, viewing your own suggestions to others, creating a new suggestion, searching through suggestions based on location
  • Where: out of class, mostly friends and relatives
  • Duration:? 5 to 10 minutes

Results

  • 5 people pressed the login-button before filling in their username and password
  • 3 people found it weird that it was indicated nowhere that a like/dislike was saved
  • 4 people didn’t find immediately that details could be opened by clicking on the suggestion
  • 2 people didn’t think it was clear that enter should be clicked before searching in the explore-screen
  • 2 people recommended replacing the navigation bar by a selection-menu
  • 2 people missed a back-button when adding an image

Conclusion

  • Not clear that user needs to enter his username and password first
  • Nowhere is shown that a like isn’t saved, should be made clearer
  • Hard to find how to open the details of a suggestion, this is a lay-out problem
  • Pressing enter before searching, not immediately clear
  • Going back without adding an image to a new recommendation should be added (easy)
  • Some people thought it was logic to have a selection-menu instead of a navigation bar.

By reading all this, it should be clear that no big problems came forward in this test. This means that no big changes are required to fix these problems. In the next iteration we can test whether the solutions to these problems satisfy the users.

Goals for the next version of the PROTOTYPE

  1. Making the login-process clearer
  2. Show that a like/dislike is saved throughout the application
  3. Clearing up the lay-out of suggestions and details
  4. Selection-menu instead of navigation bar

POSSIBLE SOLUTIONS FOR THESE PROBLEMS

  1. Login-process
    1. Social-network login
    2. Creating our own back-end with user profiles
    3. Clicking the login-button and only then showing the username and password input fields
  2. Saving and showing a like/dislike
    1. Showing a icon (e.g. thumbs up/down) in the overview
    2. Making the button already clicked when opening the details (if ?a like/dislike was recorded previously)
  3. Selection-menu instead of navigation bar
    1. Selection-menu where user can click on to select a different menu
    2. Do nothing, because only 20% of the tested persons gave this remark
  4. Lay-out of suggestions and details
    1. This is a lay-out problem, which we will consider more later.

CHOOSING A SOLUTION FOR EACH PROBLEM

  1. Social network-login. This way we don’t need to create our own back-end with profiles and friendships, this is all provided by the social-media
  2. Showing an icon in the overview as well as making the button already clicked to indicate a like or dislike
  3. For now, we will ignore this remark. If it comes up again in the future, this is relatively easy to change.

Changing?an aspect of the app due to a problem depends on:

  • ease of change, i.e. how easy it is?to solve the problem;
  • overall effect, i.e. if?solving?the problem?makes the app more consistent, easier to use, more efficient,…

Method

RX.fm, or “recs.fm”, is application that is build on top of the Last.fm API. It can be considered an extension on the Last.fm social interactions through certain tags in the users’ communication. If possible, data storage is kept at a minimum. Instead, some minor data mining is applied on user’s friend profiles to generate context for the recommendations that are interchanged between the users.

The goal is the build a mobile App that forms the interface for this enhancement of Last.fm’s social interactions. An additional chrome extension can be developed as well to allow Last.fm users to send shouts from their browser that can be interpreted by the app.

The first version of the app aims to support the following functionality:

  • Create a status to ask for recommendations related to a certain artist;
  • Reply on the status updates of friend’s to suggest a certain artist;
  • Browse the friends list;
  • Browse previously published statuses;

    • We made a paper with 3×2 keyword. For each keyword, they had to choose which of the two they felt fits the app best.

  • During the informal questionaire, we explicitly asked users what they think about the use of the word ‘stem’

Rationale:

When we let users rate a frituur using the app, many people told us things like: “This app looks great!”,? “I find it clear and easy to use.” Those comments were all nice to hear, but they are hard to use as objective measure. That’s why we let the second part of users decide between two keywords. This way we could attempt to get objective results.

Only few people seem to? have problems with the use of the word ‘stem’ when we do not explicitly ask them their opinion. So we extended the informal questionnaire with this explicit question.

Who, What, When?:

27 people that were present in the computer science building on the campus. So they were mostly students compter science.
The first part of the test (without the keywords +? stem questions) was done by 17 users, the second part by 10.

We asked the test persons to rate the frituur they last visited in Leuven. If possible, they made use of their own mobile device.

Results:

Mainly, Users follow one of these flows to get to the profile page of a frituur:

  1. Search frituren in the neighbourhood > Scroll through the (extensive) list to find the desired frituur.
  2. Search frituur by name or street > select the desired frituur form the 1-3 leftovers.

For this test, most users used the second flow (16 agiants 11) but both ways are used frequently.

Every users managed to rate the frituur that he intended to rate at the start of the test. So that’s a great success!

Out of the first 17 users, only 2 users mentioned that ‘stem’ had electoral connotation for them. But when asked explicitly, 6/10 users said this to be the case. We assume users don’t think about what to expect from this button, and when the button takes them to a rating page, they immediately adapt to the situation. Although afterwards when they think about it, it sounds more logical to them there is no rating page.

We will change the text on the button form ‘stem’ to ‘geef je mening’ to get rid of this ever returning small issue.

Most of the first 17 users mentioned that they found the app easy to use, good looking and straightforward. The last 10 users had to choose keywords. None of them choose a word on the right side of the paper. All users chose the keyword on the left. One users had no opinion for the second pair of keywords. Another user left the choice between ‘eenvoudig’ and ‘complex’ undecided.

Other issues:

We only take into account issues that returned more than once here. We will not change the app to support? solutions. This because we do not have much time left for this course and they are not issues that concern a lot of users. Moreover, most of the issues talk about extending the functionality, rathter than lacks in the current functions.

  • We noticed the search function is very strict. It has no flexibility. St. Jacobsplein for example is not the same as Sint Jacobsplein. This caused users to not find their frituur from the first time.
  • It would be nice to have a picture or logo of the frituur on the profile page, in order to a point of reference, according to 2 people.
  • 2 people clicked on the arrows that indicate the sore on a profile page, to give a frituur an immediate positive rating.
  • 3 people found the concept of the app too little.
  • The app is less easy to use on slower smart phones, the loading of pages takes a while on devices that are less performant. This causes user to make clicks they did not intent.

Conclusion:

We were really flatterd by comments that we got. People were enthusiast about our app. Of course we cannot know whether that is genuine enthusiasm. We were also glad that users managed to rate the frituren in no time.

In this post we have a closer look at all problems found during the user evaluations of iteration 3. Where applicable,?we give an explanation of our attempt to solve the problem or explain why we didn’t try solving it. We divide all problems into two categories:

  • changed,
  • unchanged.

Changing?an aspect of the app due to a problem depends on:

  • urgency, i.e. how many test users?found the problem;
  • ease of change, i.e. how easy it is?to solve the problem;
  • overall effect, i.e. if?solving?the problem?makes the app more consistent, easier to use,u2026

Changed

P3.1: The communication between the app and Facebook could be better. (n=3)

Our app now detects when a user successfully?recommends something to a Facebook friend that hasn’t used?the app before?and asks the user if he wants to let that friend know about uAdvise (image 1).

Image 1: question to invite friend

If the user chooses yes, he needs to approve of?the message that will be posted and has the possibility to enter a personal message along with it?(image 2). We’re aware that this second confirmation screen is rather redundant, but this is something we’re forced to do as Facebook uses this measure to prevent apps from randomly spamming someone’s Facebook wall.

Image 2: invitation to be sent

It’s only possible to send such an invitation when recommending?a series, movie or book?and?not when requesting because:

  • an individual?invitation makes it more personal and might convince the invitee to actually try the app;
  • if several persons of?a same circle of Facebook friends use the app and post many requests, dozens to hundreds of persons could potentially?get an overload of invitations.

P3.3: It’s not clear who receives a request. (n=1)

After successfully posting a request, a pop-up with feedback is shown. Instead of showing?a message saying: Your request was posted, we’ve added information stating that the user’s friends will receive the request (image 3).

Image 3: feedback after posting a request

P2.2: The genres?shown while requesting arenu2019t applicable to all types?and donu2019t cover all existing genres. (n=4)

For each of the three types (series, movie, book), there is a separate set of genres to choose from (image 4). This way, all possible combinations of listed genres and types actually exist.

Image 4: request screen with different genres for each type

However, not all existing genres are listed because:

  • screen size is limited and we want to display all genres?without the need?for scrolling;
  • very rare genres would be used infrequently, only cluttering the screen;
  • we want the app?to be?G rated, and?not every genre?is?suited for minors;
  • selecting a genre is optional.

P2.10: Own recommendations arenu2019t added to the activity stream. (n=3)

As stated in the blog post with solutions of iteration 2, we?felt that showing recommendations you have sent to your friends in your own activity stream?doesn’t?really has an added value to?the user because:

  • the user already knows what he suggested;
  • it fills up screen space and potentially ‘hides’ more interesting recommendations from other users.

However, after conducting more user tests, we realize that some users like to see?what they’ve?recommended?before because:

  • it’s possible to keep track of what?is recommended to whom;
  • seeing?their own recommendation appear in the activity stream is a?satisfactory kind of feedback for the user, indicating that their suggestion was?posted successfully.

As we think both sides are defendable, we’ve chosen to allow the users to choose for themselves what they prefer. By tapping the options button at the main screen (image 5, upper right corner), the options menu pops up (image 6). Aside from logging out, the user can use the toggle button to switch between hiding or showing his own suggestions.

When using the app for the first time, the option will be set to Show my suggestions by default.

Image 5: main screen

Image 6: settings with toggle button

Unchanged

P3.2: It’s not possible to select multiple genres at the request screen. (n=1)

Reason to not allow the users to select multiple genres:

  • we don’t have the room to display a lot of genres?in each?entry in?the activity list (image 5);
  • it’s like treating the other users as an advanced human search engine; it’s not something one could think of in a flash and as such, doesn’t fit with the concept of our app as a tool for quick and easy recommendations.

As the user can’t select multiple genres,?a workaround for the user?could be to:

  • not choose a genre, as it is optional;
  • post multiple requests for different genres.

P3.4: Using the app, it’s only possible to communicate with Facebook friends. (n=1)

We’ve made the choice to use Facebook because:

  • it has?the?largest user base of all social media?(1.11 billion users);
  • it fits with our concept of friends recommending to friends, unlike a system like Twitter, which makes use of followers.

To be able to communicate with more people, simply adding other social networks isn’t a good solution because:

  • there is an overlap of user bases between different social networks, minimizing the net number of persons added to the community;
  • adding a social network?adds considerably to the amount of effort on our side.

Because of these reasons, we don’t consider adding compatibility with other social networks to our app.

Facebook API

We started with the idea to persist our recommendations on Facebook. We chose for Facebook because we already used the Facebook API to handle our login and provide us with the contacts of the user.?Our application works as a one-on-one recommendation of a location that is assisted by a picture. Afterwards there can be a conversation between both users about the recommendation. In the beginning we thought that Facebook would allow us to persist and provide us all those features, but when we started the implementation, we soon encountered soms problems. All those issues were related to one subject and that is privacy. The Facebook API is able to create albums, upload images to those albums, read and write comments, but Facebook is not able to support the situation were you want to keep an album private but only accessible by one other person. After searching for a solution, we found out that in the previous versions of the (Facebook) Graph API the privacy parameter could be set to allow “Some friends”.

privacy={'value': 'CUSTOM', 'allow': 'SOME_FRIENDS', 'friends': '{friend-id-1},{friend-id-2}'}

In the latest version that feature is deprecated and it’s only possible to set the parameter to allow a certain friend list to get access to an image or album.

privacy={'value': 'CUSTOM', 'allow': '{friend-list-id}'}

These limitations of the API match by the way the absence of this feature on the website were it’s also not possible to make a picture only accessible to yourself and one friend without creating a friend list that only contains that friend. The “possible solution” would be to create a friend list for each friend with whom your share a recommendation. And when it would be possible to create invisible friend lists, we maybe would considered this option. But every friend list is visible on the Facebook website and we don’t want to pollute our users’ FB accounts, so we had to work out another option.

Backend in CodeIgniter and imgur.com

Nik came up with the idea to use the PHP framework CodeIgniter for developing our own backend. So we build some tables for the recommendations and comments and put them in a MySQL database. With the PHP framework we created some Rest (API) Controllers to handle POST- and GET-requests for sending and receiving data from the database. This worked quite well and we first wanted to implement the image upload also with the framework. But why would we reinvent the wheel, when websites like imgur.com already provide a decent image upload API?

Facebook message
To increase the reachability and to arouse some interest from other users, the application also sends a Facebook message to the receiver of the recommendation. This message consists of the image that the sender added to the recommendation and a link to our application in the Android PlayStore to invite the receiver and other people to download and use the app.

Technical application flow
So our basic application flow with the emphasis on the technical aspects:

  • 1 Login via Facebook API
  • 2a New recommendation form:
    • Coordinates via GPS/ Cell tower
    • Contacts via FB API
    • Phonegap for taking picture
  • 3a Submitting new recommendation:
    • Upload image to imgur.com via imgur API and receiving image url
    • POST-request to add the new recommendation via the REST API
    • Post message on the FB wall of the receiver of the recommendation
  • 2b Interaction list:
    • GET-request for all recommendations of the current user via the REST API
  • 3b Detail page of certain recommendation:

For this iteration we had the professor and 2 students (1 during class, the other a fellow computer scientist) test the application.

Since we also asked the users to explain what they saw on each screen they did get curious enough to try out all the buttons. This way we never had to ask to do a specific task, but also made it harder to tell how they would use the application normally.

Results:

All 3 users had remarks about the sliders. One of them said he expected numbers on a slider. Another one explicitly said that it’s not really a slider since it has only 3 options.They all tried to give some alternatives, like using radio buttons or just 3 actual buttons. None of them were really convinced about “the best” way to do it though.

One user had a remark about the alignment, which wasn’t perfect only because we quickly created it in powerpoint by dragging everything to where it should be.

None of the users experienced any trouble with creating a new recommendation except for one that didn’t follow the order in which he entered the data for the recommendation. This only caused problems because of the way we implemented this in powerpoint, it would not be a problem in a fully working version.

We actually had to give that explanation quite often during the test: “This button/click/filter/<insert other functionality> doesn’t really do what you expect here just because how limited the implementation in powerpoint is. Please pretend that this shows <insert correct thing to be shown> or please pretend that you clicked that recommendation and that you thus see more information about that one.”

We thus decided that the combination of our lacking powerpoint implementation with the nature of our test wasn’t really going to work. Because the remaining time for the course was rather limited as well we then chose to create a fully functional version of our application that would have only the very basic functionalities required to use the app. These functionalities are:

  • creating a recommendation
  • showing more information about a recommendation
  • showing the list with received and sent recommendations
  • the basic filters for “from me” and “to me”, not the advanced filters

We made our prototype in powerpoint this time. This means that the implementation was very limited to what was actually possible. We had 4 versions of our main screen. One showing some received and previously sent recommendations. One showing only received recommendations. One with a bigger version of a recommendation showing more details (this would be shown if the user clicks a received one). And the last one that would show the recommendation that the user just created.

It should be noted that only the “to me” check box actually did something here, since we did not make a separate screen for the “from me” button. Besides that we also had a screen for creating a new recommendation and one for the advanced filters:

In this last screen the sliders actually did change position and changed the explanation underneath them depending on where the new position of the slider. After successfully (?) participating in this course, it is time to look back and formulate a reflection about it. We will do this by itemising some thoughts:

* First of all, the lectures were intensive (long duration), but there was a nice alternation between working moments and moments of watching related videos. On the other hand, it was good to do some little presentation, but by listening to all the presentations of the other teams, a lot of time was not used efficiently. It would have been better to just work on the application, because a lot of teams still had a lot of work to do to go live with their app.

* The total amount of study points does certainly match with the amount of working load. You have to spend around 120 hours to achieve the goal.

* It was difficult to get started. The abstract assignment was given and within an hour we had to know the subject of our application. This is too less time to get up with an idea that differentiates your app with the existing applications. You also have to work on it for a whole semester, so you should better think twice about your subject.

* Blogging is a nice way of reporting about the work you’ve done. It’s less boring than writing a report and you can follow the progress of other teams.

* Twittering (and also blogging) was an added value in the beginning of the course. But its activity went down for a lot of teams when reaching the end of the course.

* We did not take the badge-system as a motivation. The result of the application is more important that trying to earn new badges.

* The course is not only about where to put graphical elements, but it is also about how and why a user makes use of the application (statistics). If a user does not use a certain functionality, it’s not worth doing a lot of tests for the functionality. This should have been stressed earlier in the course.

* Very nice is the atmosphere within the HCI-group. The distance between the participants and the assistants/professor is very small.

* People should certainly take this course if they are interested in the user-interaction of applications. They should also not be afraid to communicate with possible users and to ask for their thoughts.

Test Method + Rationale

We introduced 10 students to our application and handed them a survey. Then, we let them do as they pleased. The data we would be getting were the survey, consisting of a SUS test and two free-form feedback/suggestions questions, together with the usage logs. A System Usability Scale test is a standardised 10 question multiple choice test used for assessing the usability of a system, where ‘system’ can refer to anything that has a user interface. SUS tests are handy to compare different iterations to each other (not applicable in this case) and to check whether there is a problem, but not for what that problem would be. For that reason we also included the free-form questions.

Using this test method, the test persons would feel minimal pressure while testing and reviewing the application, which we think resulted in honest and realistic results.

Results

Despite having an ok SUS score (77.1, the average for any SUS test is 68) one question in particular did not receive a good response: “I think that I would like to use this system frequently.” The reason for this was apparent from the free-form questions; 6 out of 10 users indicated that they had no need for our website, existing social media websites (mostly Facebook) were already good enough. Furthermore 4 out of 10 users said they did not have a Twitter-account (and presumably wouldn’t want to make one just for this).

The solutions is one we earlier said we planned to do but didn’t because of time-constraints: Facebook and Google login. It takes care of the second large concern and by making the website available to users of these social media websites we further emphasize what we think is the largest benefit of using Recommend Thing: having all your recommendations in one place.

Solutions

Some lesser concerns are already addressed as well in the version that is now online

  • Some users wanted to see more clearly to/from whom a recommendation was, we solved this by adding the user avatars
  • Nearly no one made recommendations to multiple people, “Add contact” was changed to “Add contacts”
  • Usage logs showed that nobody even tried to invite another users, so we made the invite option in the “Add contacts” menu more visible

It would be nice to know how these changes influenced user behaviour. Sadly, no JeTS-CHI team members will be having time to figure this out in the coming weeks due to exams.

Reflection

As a last note we have some reflections on the course ‘User Interfaces’:

  • It was nice to design an application from the user’s perspective. We learned that it is truly a different way of developing than what we were used to, like in a lot more iterations.
  • It’s only by trying, that you can learn how to test an application on its users. Now we see that some tactics we chose in the beginning were maybe not the best decisions. But we learned from our mistakes. For example: Deciding to strip down our app to the bare minimum, and relying on the advise of the users which features to add: this leads to an app that has several well known and popular features, but it does not make a great app. A well thought-of concept makes an app stand out, look at ChiConCarne’s app! We learned in this course that we have to listen to the users, but we as developers still have the last word.
  • Working with blogs and Twitter is a good way to learn from each other. In the beginning there was some doubt about the system but actually it should be used more often for project courses.

It was certainly an experience to work with paper prototypes and to see how fast usability problems can be found in the early stages of development. The five and a half hour sessions did discourage us a bit before we started the course. But in the end it wasn’t that long, probably because of the interactivity of the classes. And this format is certainly better than splitting the course into multiple classes/week.

We think this course was a great introduction to the ‘human’ side of computer science.

    I felt that before the last iteration, there were still some significant issues that needed addressing to ensure a certain level of quality. Using short development cycles with a limited amount of test users, made it possible to incrementally improve the application at a relatively fast tempo. Applying techniques such as usage tracking, might not have given the same level of detail as users tend to be less willing to give feedback compared to face-to-face evaluations. I assume this would be a risk especially when the application usage is low. On the other hand, in terms of recommendation trust, the application did provide an additional functionality by combining Last.fm’s recommendations with perhaps more compelling recommendation by peers.

Overall a good presentation with nice slides. (Unfortunately we did not get the opportunity to hear Alex’s sped up voice, which he assured me, would have been very funny.) Let’s get the elephant out of the room right away: we don’t regret at all choosing (or having to choose) User Interfaces?as a course. In that sense, there may very well never has been an elephant in the room to begin with. Nevertheless, we feel it’s a refreshing approach to have such a limited amount of theory before we’re able to get started. It’s a bit like learning how to drive a car: it’s not that much about the theory, it’s about the techniques.

Having said that, initially, it was hard to know when to shift from the first iteration to the next or what even an iteration was supposed to be, so it was a satisfactory aha moment when we saw slides 8 and 9 of this presentation. We really recommend that these slides are shown much sooner during the course, as it really helps create an idea of what is about to come and what the course is about. At the end of the course it is time for some reflections on this course. What was noticeable, what we learned and whatu2019s important for us to keep remembering.

Creating an application

The most important thing that we learned is to take the completely different viewpoint from the user into account. The user of an application doesnu2019t think like the developer of that application. And no matter how the user thinks, heu2019s always right. This means that you as developer should adapt your application to fit the user. It should never be the other way around, i.e. the user adapting himself to the application.

Another important thing is that you can keep trying to improve your application more and more, but anyone will at some point need users to test and improve the user interface. You cannot make a good interface without testing with users. The issues with opening the OLPC illustrates the importance of everything said above.

Further it is also necessary that you do multiple iterations to improve the design. You canu2019t write the perfect application from scratch. It will need improvements (for which you will test with users), and you will need to test those improvements (again with users) to see if they were effective. Designing a good user interface is thus an iterative process in which you keep testing and improving the interface.

Getting test users

We also experienced some problems in getting enough test users to thoroughly test our application. People in our environment, like friends and family, were willing enough, but at some point we had to get out of that circle, to get results from people who don’t have any bias. (Friends and family tend to be a little kinder about problems they encounter with things you’ve made).

Getting those extra users ‘in the wild’ proved extremely hard. Even with the contest we set up, to give the users an incentive for really using our app, we only got around 80 unique visitors to use our app. If we would’ve had more time, we might have experienced with some other techniques to get more users.

About the set-up of the course

To start with, we think 5,5h session are loooong. On one hand this is useful, because we really got things done when we worked on the project for so long at once. But on the other hand, concentration gets lost very easily near the end of the session.

Another option would be two session a week, both taken up 3h or so, but it might be hard to get do everything that has to be done together (like giving those little presentations, brainstorming-storyboarding-prototyping, ..) in a 3h session.

Finally, we liked the fact that the reports were replaced by the tweeting and blogging. This gives you the possibility to keeping track of yourself and the other teams and also to react to and get feedback from other teams (and from the professor and his assistants as well).

The course “Gebruikersinterfaces” (UIs) is highly practical and aimed at applying a evaluation techniques for usability in applications. The teaching strategy consisted mainly out of presentations with slides, some video material and supervised exercises to put theory into practice. The blog served as a means for self-reflection and combined with Twitter, as a communication channel between students and teaching staff.

In a paper by Petkovic et al. [1] a similar teaching strategy is applied for course on software engineering, although apart from usability aspects there was also a strong focus on software quality. Some of the results presented in this paper were the following:

  • “The focus of the class was on methods, processes, teamwork, communication and design for usability, and not on software architectures or programming techniques” [1]. Petkovic et al. indicate that it was important to stress this at the beginning of the course [1]. In the UIs course this was indeed made clear from the beginning: the applications will be not be graded in terms of software quality.

    Still, many of the teams spent significant time to develop the back-end of their applications. Perhaps some additional guidance in this area would be welcome for future projects. Perhaps promoting groups to work with the same user database would also help, this might increase the usage of the applications as test users wouldn’t need new login data to test each separate prototype.
  • An interesting perspective that is used in [1] is that instructors take on the role of “management, tech leads, and users”. In the course UIs this was also the case, although I feel the course lacks some of the more managerial aspects. Most of the projects lack some concrete “vision”. This might have caused the relatively low usage of the apps. Differentiating an application among the thousands that are out there on the market is not easy, and perhaps I would have hoped that from the teaching staff’s experience over the years, there would have been more feedback in that department. This is probably reflected as well in the variety of approaches by students to spread their applications.
  • “Grading policies should reflect and encourage adherence to software engineering methods, group interaction and iterations, and not be based only on the final delivery” [1]. Intriguingly, they claim that students would actually have been less motivated if their interactions would have been graded. I assume that the badge system and quantified self methods may form the middleground in this discussion, although results of that study will probably provide insight.

All in all I think the idea behind the course is good. The course material is perhaps rather limited. Of course students can find theoretical sources, books, websites, papers et cetera anywhere online nowadays, but more concrete references to this kind of material would be welcome. What the course material lacks most, are perhaps much more concrete examples, simple as well as real applications of techniques. Reading about a recipe is still something else as seeing someone make it, but perhaps Jeroen Meus’s success is actually built on a tasty accent and hand gestures.

[1] Dragutin Petkovic, Gary Thompson, and Rainer Todtenhoefer. 2006. Teaching practical software engineering and global software engineering: evaluation and comparison. SIGCSE Bull. 38, 3 (June 2006), 294-298. DOI=10.1145/1140123.1140202 http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/1140123.1140202

Tuesday, February 19th, after a brief course introduction by professor Duval on the concepts of user interface design, we received the assignment to evaluate the social media website http://www.pinterest.com. Each group prepared a couple of tasks to be executed by another group. By observing the time and effort it takes to perform the given tasks, we can evaluate the ease of use of pinterest.

The first task we composed was to find a funny picture of a cat. The evaluation started when the user was logged in and looking at the main page. At first, the user clicked on the category named “animals” but none of the displayed pictures contained a funny cat. After a few seconds, the person decided to use the search function with the term “funny cat” and immediately found the kind of picture he was looking for. This gives us the information that the search function is a very intuitive way to find a specific pin and it didn’t take long for the subject to find the requested image.

The next assignment was to share a picture of a certain person named Sarah Dunleavy. The first action of the user was to enter the given name in the search box, which led him to the results page which didn’t contain any result. However, the user didn’t notice that the page had fully loaded and mistakenly thought that the page was still loading. After a minute, he tried to look for the first name only but this didn’t give any info related to the user he was looking for. Only then, he noticed that the results page had an option to display search results for pins, boards and pinners. After selecting the third option, the subject immediately found the person Sarah Dunleavy and fluently shared one of her images. This tells us that the different search options aren’t as obvious as they should be. Another thing to notice is that it is not clear if no results are found, because our user thought that the page was still loading. On the other hand, sharing a pin didn’t cause any problems and was very straightforward to do.

The following task was to find a way to send a mail to the support team of Pinterest. The first action of the user was to click on the “About” link at the top of the page and then he immediately went to the page about the Pinterest team. After about ten seconds of searching, he couldn’t find a possibility to mail the support so he clicks on the help link. On the help page, our user selects the “contacting” topic and gets an explanation of the mail function. However, a real option to send a mail is still not available. Another minute of random link browsing eventually leads to the page to report bugs which contains an option to send a mail. With this information we can conclude that it is easy to find an explanation of the email function but it’s hard to find the actual email function itself. It could be indicated more clearly that a user has to open a subject first, before the email function is accessible.

At last, our user was instructed to create a secret board about art. Still in the help section, the user clicks on the main logo to return to the homepage of Pinterest. He then clicks the “Add” button and selects the option to create a new board. Altogether this only took about 20 seconds. This indicates that it is very straightforward and intuitive to create a new board. The required options like making the board secret are conveniently presented to the user.

With these observations, we can conclude that new users easily get accustomed to Pinterest as long as they don’t have a problem and need to mail the support. The user of the “Add” button is very straightforward and doesn’t require any extra explanation. Searching for a certain keyword is also easy but the option to search for a board or user instead of a pin can be displayed more clearly. Along with this information, we learned that this way of evaluating an interface is a very effective and efficient way to gather information about the design of a user interface and we will certainly be applying it in our next assignments. However, we must keep in mind that the quality of the evaluation depends on the amount and diversity of the tasks that we give to our test audience.

Tuesday we did a first evaluation exercise. We tried to evaluate the User Interface of the http://pinterest.com website. We were divided into different groups.

Each group had to think of a series of tests to be executed by another group. Although we already had some time to check out the pinterest website (and therefore the tests could be a bit biased) there were still some issues to be found with the website when conducting the tests. We used the following tests to see if there were some issues to be found, each test is followed by our observations and, if applicable, ?by a possible solution.

  • Create a board that would serve the purpose of grouping everything of a specific interest of the user.

This worked great. The user had no issues whatsoever. The user easily found the button to add a board via the Add-popup.

  • Add a Pin to the previously created board that the user could find on the website.

The user found the pin of its interest easily by selecting the category of his interest. However when trying to pin the Pin of his interest to the board there were some issues. The user scrolled down and up to look for the button to pin it to his board. This button is called the repin button and it seems that the concept is not clear to a first time user. Maybe this could be clearer by just stating what it does i.e. pin to board.

  • Add a Pin from an external website to the previously created board.

There were no issues here.

  • Search for any available mobile apps for the website.

This was a big problem! The user could not find the page he was looking for. One would think that Pinterest would like users to incorporate Pinterest in their daily lives by using the smartphone app on the go. However there was no clear indication that such an app existed. There was one page that stated that there was an iOS and Android app available but it was very hard to find. The user would land on the page if he clicked on the “pin it button”-link in the about menu. Which in my opinion has nothing to do with a mobile app. This became clear when the user did the test, he first clicked the Pinterest logo to go to the home page. Afterwards he clicked the ?category, account settings, business links. Each of these clicks are followed by a huge amount of scrolling to look for an indication for a smartphone app. Finally the user clicked the correct link. To make this clearer I would include a small android and iOS logo in the top bar or include a smartphone button in the about menu.

An online pin board used to share things with others. Hard to imagine? Try surfing to Pinterest. Pinterest jumps on the social network bandwagon with this simple, but potentially addicting concept. However, the process of getting familiarised with this site is not exactly a bed of roses. Spending about an hour on Pinterest evaluating the user interface and observing the behaviour of other persons using the site led to following conclusions.

The page the user gets to see after logging in.

At first sight, new users could feel a bit overwhelmed by the amount of pictures being shown. It certainly doesn’t help that they are obliged to choose at least five interests. That means tough luck for the user if he is (initially) only interested in two or three things. Also, the randomness of displaying pictures of chosen interests and the inability to easily reorganise these pictures make the screen look a bit chaotic. Uninteresting images could be cluttering the upper part of the page, banishing the potentially more relevant or user-appealing bits of interest to lower regions of the page. This opposes the purpose of this and other similar social sharing networks: the more is shared, the more interesting it gets. Unfortunately, on Pinterest, it also gets a bit more chaotic.

Having many pictures on one page means the user has to scroll down to see more. Aside from the downsides of downloading every single picture on screen and occasionally a freezing browser while scrolling down, the ‘scroll to top’ button is a welcome shortcut to the top of the page (although one could just use the ‘Home’ button, found on most keyboards).

Shortcut button to the top of the page.

Clicking on one of the pictures displays a larger version of it. While the picture is downloading, a loading animation is being shown, but the user can’t scroll down to the comments. Due to the position of this animation, if the picture is too large to fit the screen, the user can’t see that something is happening and can’t scroll down to see the animation; potentially thinking the application is unresponsive.

When finding an interesting picture, it is rather simple to pin or repin, follow or unfollow it. However, pinning a new picture can be a hassle if the user doesn’t know the URL of that picture. Also, each pinned picture requires a specific board to which it is pinned and a comment, which is the only way of finding a specific picture, thus solely relying on the description given by the pinner when searching for it. In other words, the search function doesn’t search for displayed objects, but for matching words in the given description, which could be misleading.

Writing a comment on a picture works like expected, but instead of providing more regularity and diminishing chaos, only some pictures on the new user’s main page have a comment field. Although, clicking on any picture allows writing a comment. Many users are also accustomed to pressing enter when done writing to post the comment, however, Pinterest requires the user to click the post button.

Like all other social networks, Pinterest requires new users to register. Aside from the fact that it isn’t possible to register by clicking on ‘login’, in some cases, the user trying to register is greeted with an error, which is displayed in English, irrespective of the language set by the user. Not only is the text describing the error displayed in a very subtle way, it also is too generic and doesn’t give the user a hint of what went wrong. Did the user do something wrong? Could it depend on the browser used? Perhaps new users couldn’t register due to site maintenance? Well, at least we’re told to try again ‘later’.

Last session consisted of three big parts, brainstorming about the assignment, creating one or multiple storyboards and designing a paper prototype.

The assignment can be summarised as this:

An application that allows someone to recommend something to someone else.

For example, if person X sees a beautiful building and he/she wants to tell person Y he/she should come see it, person X can recommend the building to person Y.

To get more ideas, interpretations and explore the topic and its possibilities more in-depth, we had a brainstorm session, described below.

Brainstorming

After professor Duval explained the assignment, the first thing we had to do was brainstorm about it. We sat together with another team (Team S-CHI), to come up with ideas, this because 2-3 people is too small a group for brainstorming.

The most important rule for this brainstorming session was: no criticism. Every idea was valuable in this stage, even the most far-fetched ones. Quantity over quality!

This was the result of our brainstorm:

Or in more readable form:

We’ve also included a ‘translation’ for those of you who do not speak Dutch:

In the beginning of the brainstorm session, our main focus was around recommending in the centre with possibilities such as ‘re-recommending’, questions, etc. Afterwards our focus shifted more towards users and the different possibilities associated with them.
You can also see that we came up with a lot of ‘types’ of recommendations. Note also the people subtopic. More on that later when we talk about storyboarding.
The concept of liking and disliking recommendations other people made for you, seemed also very appealing. By counting likes and dislikes of recommendations someone made, a user could gain some credibility, or trustworthiness.

Since it isn’t possible for us to focus on all these things, we had to select some of them. We decided that the ideas we would pursue, were the recommendation of places, and things from which you can make pictures.

Storyboarding

After the brainstorming, we were ready to draw some storyboards. A storyboard is a kind of comic that tells a story of one or more users and how they would use the application. It is important to focus on the story and not the way the user interacts with the application, only what he uses the application for.

An easy way to draw users is as ‘star people’, you can see our star people in the images below. Star people are just little people with a star for a body, which is easy to draw. To make a distinction between different star people, we also added some geometries.

We made two storyboards:

This storyboard tells the story of the ‘triangle user’. The triangle user sees a nice building and uses the application to recommend the building to the ‘square user’. Then the square user goes to see the building himself, finds he likes it too and decides to like the recommendation the triangle user made.
In the second storyboard we told the story of a male user who recommends a girl or a woman to another male user. In this context, recommending a person means, to us anyway, that some user indicates that he/she thinks the other user will like the recommended person and should get to know him/her.

The reaction to this storyboard was somewhat divided. It seems like a fun idea, during brainstorming, to recommend people to other people, but it is easy for users to misuse this possibility and for the application to deteriorate to that use only. With current social media as an example, posting photos of other people on the web can lead to very painful situations.

After the storyboarding, we decided to keep the idea of recommendations of places and the possibility to like or dislike a recommendation someone made to you.

Paper Prototyping

The last part of the session was dedicated to the creation of a prototype of the application we had in mind. Not a digital prototype, but a paper prototype. This means that we should be able to test the most important functionality of the actual application interface with this prototype.

A paper prototype consists of just a couple of screens, shown by the application, drawn on paper. You can test the functionality of the prototype by letting the user push imaginary buttons on the paper screen in front of him and, depending on the button he pushed, putting another paper screen in front of him or putting a post-it, which functions as a pop-up, on top of the current screen.

In our paper prototype the user is able to recommend places to other people, get an overview of his own recommendations and view all the recommendations, or ‘suggestions’ as we called them, other users made to him.

We also chose the name ‘What’s Up’ for the application, but of course this, and also the design, can change after we get some feedback.

We designed the following screens:

Login Screen (upper left)

This screen allows the user to login or sign-up.

Suggestions (upper middle)

This is the screen where all the suggestions, that the user received, are displayed. If the user liked or disliked a suggestion, it’s marked in red or green. Different colour intensities offer the possibility to have a more detailed scale.

Suggestion Detail (upper right)

The suggestion detail screen shows the detailed information of a single suggestion and allows the user to rate it.

My Recommendations (center left)

Yesterday, Tuesday February 19th, we had our first session of the course User Interfaces. First professor Erik Duval explained the general concepts of human-computer interaction and that it was very important to look at software systems from the user-side of things.

You can find more information about this course, the other teams and their blogs on http://ariadne.cs.kuleuven.be/wiki/index.php/Chi_2013 .

It was immediately clear that in designing a useful interface, it is important to iterate over the design. You need to design, evaluate and implement (notice the order!), test and look for problems at least a couple of times, so you can filter out problems.

To get a first touch with evaluating a user interface, our assignment was to write down all pros and cons of the Pinterest-application (http://pinterest.com).

The most pressing problems we identified with the user interface Pinterest provided were the following:

  • When you don’t have an account and you’re browsing the main page, there is always box that gives you the?possibility to login or to register. Even when you scroll down, the box stays on top of your screen, so you can’t really do a lot when you’re not registered and logged in, as you can see in the image below. Pinterest quite firmly pushes you into registering.
  • Secondly, we thought it was annoying that Pinterest automatically chose some privacy settings when registering. An example is that the setting, which indicates that Google shows your Pinterest-profile in their search results, is automatically turned ON. (Actually, the setting that Google doesn’t show your profile is turned OFF, but this means the same thing). You can easily turn this feature OFF in the settings of your profile, but if you don’t think of that, it will obviously remain ON forever. We realize that this isn’t a point of concern for most users, but it would be nice if Pinterest just asked this while creating your profile.
  • Also, once you’re logged in, the page you see, your main page, is very unstructured and busy. You don’t really know where to look first or what to do.
  • At last, the whole concept of ‘pinning’ wasn’t clear to us in the beginning. When you click the ‘add’-button, you will see the screen below. A first-time user won’t know what to do with this, so it would be nice if there was some extra information.

On the other hand Pinterest did some things very good:

  • It was very clear to the user how to login or how to create an account. The process for creating an account was very easy (only if an account couldn’t be created, the error message didn’t indicate the problem, just that there was a problem).
  • It immediately addressed us in the correct language.
  • The menu bar with categories follows while you scroll down the page.

The second part of the lecture we had to put the interface to the test. We had to think of some tasks other people had to do and observe which problems they encountered when executing these tasks.

First we asked them to create a board and ‘repin’ someone else’s picture on that board. Because these people had gained some experience with Pinterest in the mean time, they didn’t have any problems with this.

Next we asked them to find one of our profiles and follow us. Searching for something was easy, the search bar is right on top of the main page. But when you search for something, the search results that are displayed, are ‘pins’ not people. To find the search results on people, you had to click on ‘pinners’, which wasn’t immediately clear to the test users.

Finally we asked them to locate the help page. The link to the help page is located in the ‘about’ dropdown-menu, so it is only visible when you move your mouse over this menu. When doing this test, we also noticed it was very hard to contact Pinterest, i.e. send them an e-mail. To do this, you first had to choose a topic that was related to your problem and only then a button with ‘email help’ was shown.

These problems aren’t really big issues for most of the users, so based on this we can conclude that the user interface provided by Pinterest is very useful and usable.

That way you can get so many ideas floating around, there’s bound to be some good ones in there. It didn’t take more than a few minutes, but afterwards we had a pretty good idea of what we wanted: a recommendation system focused on the idea of personal recommendations, as opposed to recommending things to anyone who will listen (the latter is more ‘sharing’ than it is ‘recommending’).

We had an idea, now we needed to refine it; time to bring in storyboarding. Using a storyboard, you can show how you intend for people to use your product.
