The Introduction

This week, we had our first class of the course UI.?This course discusses the often-underestimated topic?of how to create a valuable, engaging user experience tailored to an application’s target audience, the technology used and the task the application needs to perform. The lecture addressed the general ideas behind human-computer interaction, and an introduction to the evaluation of user interfaces.

A summary of some of the concepts we have learned about can be found here.

Evaluation of the Pinterest website

Among the activities and lectures in the class, we were tasked with testing out the social media website Pinterest?to try?and find both good and bad elements of its UI and the user experience when using the application for what it?is intended. Among these factors were not only the buttons and text boxes that are displayed, but also how long it took to figure out how certain functionalities work, as well as what Pinterest is used for.

We used two methods. The first was a rather naive and straightforward method. The second method was a particular evaluation technique often used for real usability studies, called the think aloud protocol.

A quick evaluation

As a first step, we needed to observe the application ourselves and discuss our findings. The positive points that were gleaned from this short testing session are listed in Table 1.

Table 1 : positives and negatives detected on the Pinterest website during a quick evaluation.

Positive
  • Registration is straightforward. A mere press of a single button that is clearly and centrally displayed is all that is required.
  • The general interface on the front page is simple and takes little time to understand. This is due to the fact that most functionality is a mere one to two clicks away and all buttons/dropdown lists have text describing what they are there for. This makes navigation quick and easy for newcomers and experts.
  • Most UI elements are located at the top, this includes any functionality and the search textbox. Below these are all the pinned images. This once more illustrates easy access.
  • The point of the entire website is quickly understood: a platform for sharing media in the form of images, video and more. Nothing beyond the front page feed is required to understand this, illustrating a good design that can quickly draw in ‘accidental’ visitors to the site or people who were only mildly curious. Both of these would quickly close the tab if they didn’t quickly understand what the site was all about.
  • The About tab is concise and to-the-point, allowing for any questions to be resolved quickly. However, the help topics are perhaps a bit too simple, meaning contacting an admin is required for anything beyond the basic functionality.
  • Creating boards and pinning media is easy to figure out as text and images guide you through the process. However, anything beyond the basics of these functionalities becomes unclear due to the absence of text or labels (contradictory how they do it in one place but then don’t in another).
Negative
  • Errors in registration are reported through vague and unhelpful messages. For example: Registration continued to fail on the laptop we were using and the only help we were offered came in the form of a message that did not specify what went wrong and said to ‘try again later’; what is later? This would quickly result in casual visitors losing interest.
  • Upon registering, we were automatically following several individuals on the site and also had a board that we had not created that seemed to contain random images. As far as we understand, this is merely to show what can be done, but only results in confusion.
  • The button to unfollow an individual is grayed out and looks like a typical ‘disabled’ button, making a user think they can’t actually click it.
  • The site isn’t fully compatible with all drivers. For example, when looking at an image, the image is zoomed in and a semi-opaque white color is drawn across the background to ‘fade it out’ and focus the attention on the image and other UI elements. However, this opaque background does not function as intended in Chrome, in which it is a solid white background. This created confusion in how to return to the front page feed, which is normally done by clicking the opaque background. Instead of an overlay, it looked like a different page.
  • ‘Gifts’ are poorly explained and seem, at first sight, like a rather random thing to add to the site’s lineup of functionality. Perhaps a different name or some kind of basic information needs to be added for it to become more accessible.

Afterwards, each group had to give the issue they were most concerned about. Interestingly, these issues diverged. Even when considering the top three issues discovered by each group, there was remarkably little overlap.

Our main concern was the lack of information given by the system when an error occurred while making a new account. Professor Duval also pointed out that the language of the error message (English) did not match the language of the website (Dutch in our case).

Evaluation with the think aloud technique

After this session, we were tasked to use what we learned about evaluating a user interface and give small, atomic assignments to another team. These assignments would revolve around using Pinterest and, while the testers performed these tasks, we would have to observe their actions and listen to their feedback or ‘out-loud thoughts’.

We gave our testers the following tasks:

  • Create a board;
  • Pin an image from a googled url to this board;
  • Look up media of a specific interest that someone else posted;
  • Follow that user.

We observed the following points:

  • Adding a board was done quickly and effortlessly, in no small part due to the presence of the Add+ button in the upper right corner.
  • When creating a board, inviting someone can be a bit confusing as one needs to enter the name, but pressing the enter key does not add this person to the list of invitees, one has to press the appropriate button of the UI instead.
  • When the board is empty, it can be a bit confusing to use as the screen has very few indications present that the user is actually *in* the board.
  • There is little to no indication when adding a pin what information needs to be filled in where. Also, it is unclear that, when a user pastes in an url that they can cycle through all the images Pinterest finds on this page. The ‘prev’ and ‘next’ buttons are simply too ambiguous, especially if you enter an URL that goes directly to a single image, since there will be nothing to cycle through.
  • Commenting, repinning and searching is as easy as creating a board.
  • Browsing through results is identical to browsing through the front page feed, which makes it all the easier to learn how to use.

Final thoughts

In short, Pinterest has its share of problems, but they are mostly minor and the application is generally straigthforward and easy to use. It would benefit from a few more labels and other textual indications to go with UI fields that can/must be filled out when performing certain tasks (such as pinning). The creators of the application did make a few odd decisions. Much of their UI is straightforward to use and clearly marked, so why are other parts so ambiguous and why did they stop this modus operandi there?

Regardless, the application does what it needs to and is easy to see why it is popular since the UI is simple and one doesn’t have to be an expert with a computer (or even just a browser) to know how to navigate most of its day-to-day functionality.

Our CHI course let us take an early dive into the world of user interfaces with a simple exercise during the first class. Our assignment was to evaluate the usability of Pinterest‘s interface by letting other students perform -seemingly- simple tasks. For each task, we took informal notes on the effectiveness (was the task completed?), efficiency (how well did the task go?) and satisfaction (did the user enjoy the task?) of performing the tasks. Each student had to be both evaluator and evaluatee at least once. Rather than separating theory from practice, this little experiment gave us an immediate raw experience of how usability is a complex issue with many facets. Next we will discuss some of the tasks performed and our results. Some tasks were very similar to those executed by other groups as well. It will be interesting to compare the results!

Task 1: Pin any topic containing a picture of Lego bricks on one of your boards.

  • Effectiveness: The task was completely performed.
  • Efficiency: The user needed only 5 mouseclicks to perform the task. There were no repeated or unnecessary actions done by the user.
  • Satisfaction: The user seemed to browse pinterest’s with a breeze though he stated not to be familiar with the interface at all.

Task 2: Send an e-mail to Pinterest’s customer support.

  • Effectiveness: The task was completely performed.
  • Efficiency: The user needed a substantial amount of mouseclicks and time to perform the task. He also needed to read certain parts of the site to know how to locate the correct sections. Some actions had to be repeated to complete the task.
  • Satisfaction: There were moments the user was confused about what to do next. It’s unclear whether Pinterest tried too hard to be helpful (the help center is huge!) or if they didn’t try enough (please don’t bother us with your e-mails).

Task 3: Pin any topic of user XYZ on one of your boards.

  • Effectiveness: The task was completely performed.
  • Efficiency: There were no repeated or unnecessary actions done by the user.
  • Satisfaction: The user already knew what the tricky part of this task was (namely, when searching for something, you have to search for ‘pinners’ and not for ‘boards’) but he seemed to remember it well.

Task 4: Make it so a certain pin on the Pinterest homepage will no longer appear for you.

  • Effectiveness: The task was completely performed.
  • Efficiency: The user tried some unneceassary actions before the task was completed.
  • Satisfaction: The way Pins are laid out on the homepage seems to suggest a customazible tile interface with simple delete, move or edit functionality but this is not the case. You have to open the pin and unfollow the original author of that pin. This results in the removal of ALL pins from that author. This is not always desirable.

Our little test yielded ambigious results. The effectivity was 100%, but the user was challenged sometimes to achieve this score as indicated by a mediocre efficiency and satisfaction (disregarding the bias on task 3). Of course this shallow evaluation is by no means an in-depth review of Pinterest’s good, bad and ugly. Nonetheless we already experienced two fundamental concepts about interface design mentioned during the class:

  • You can’t achieve 100% usability: it’s a trade-off between many factors (in this case we commared effectiveness, efficiency and satisfaction)
  • You don’t need a large crowd to discover a large amount of issues with an interface (or, to discover what isn’t issue).

In the first introductory lesson, we looked more closely at what it is that makes a good user interface.

Obviously, there is no ‘silver bullet’ answering this question. However, a good user interface generally satisfies three domains: efficiency, effectiveness and (user) satisfaction. Some users will value one of these domains more than the others, while others have different thoughts on the subject.

Anyway, the main assignment in the first lesson was having a closer look at Pinterest, a website which lets people ‘pin’ and share all kinds of stuff they find interesting on the internet.

More specifically, following tasks were to be performed:

  • Work a bit with Pinterest. Do you get what it is all about? Can you do the stuff you want to do? Is the user interface clear or confusing at times? …
  • Review what the different teams came up with in the first step.
  • Perform a ‘real’ user experience test, where the people acting as?guinea-pigs had to do Pinterest tasks dictated by the team.

In the initial goofing around with Pinterest, one of the first things the team noticed was that error messages on Pinterest are rather cryptic. Things like ‘An error has?occurred,?please try again later’ or error messages presented in Portuguese aren’t very?helpful?to the user.

Another thing that bothered us were the popups at account creation?issuing?the new user to?immediately?follow 5 topics of interest. There didn’t seem to be a way to close these things, and as a new user, it wasn’t really clear what the consequences of following these topics would be.

Once the set up phase was finished however, the interface was rather intuitive (to us) to use.

When comparing the issues the different teams had come up with, one thing to note was the lack of?similarities?between them. A nice illustration of the different needs of different users it seems

Performing the user experience tests revealed a better insight in how users interact with Pinterest. The testers had to think aloud while performing the actions we told them to do. Finding and following another user was something all testers had problems with. The only solution seemed to use the personal pinterest-url of the wanted user to get to their profile page, from where it was possible to follow them.?Definitely?something Pinterest might want to look into.

If one thing became clear from the first lesson, it was that?criticizing a user interface is easy enough, but really pinning down the problems and coming up with a solution to them certainly is not.

More requirements were not necessary because a brainstorm session was coming up.

The Brainstorm
Everybody knows what a brainstorm is. But I guess most of the people know what a brainstorm should do but not really how you do it. So it was interesting to see some basic brainstorm rules:

  • Go quantity, not quality
  • Absolutely no criticism
  • Weird ideas are welcome
  • Transform others’ ideas
  • Got a stupid idea? Say it out loud. Just to get rid of it.

After this short lesson/explanation we teamed up to start the brainstorming. We realized it is harder than it looks, especially the weird idea’s don’t come out that easy. You still have this little voice in you head that says: ‘Don’t say that, it sucks, think of something better’. But actually you need a voice that says:?’Say that, it’ sucks, but it will make someone else think of something better’. Luckily the brainstorm spirit started after some minutes and we managed to get some good ideas. I will now present two result pictures of our brainstorm session and after the pictures I give you the most valuable ideas. The text is sometimes in Dutch, we apologize for this.

So just to give you a better idea I will highlight 4 ideas (not ordered) that we think were very valuable, I did not include trivial ones likes comments,friends et cetera.

  1. Fast Input-Output: The application can have a lot of features, but giving and receiving recommendations is the core. So it should be possible to do these actions without any the least possible effort (Bookmarklets, push messages,..)
  2. Gamification: There should be a motivation to make good recommendations, so every user could get a level of trust based on ratings that receivers can give.
  3. Global stats: It would be cool if we could also explore recommendation from out the world, so for example which YouTube movies are recommended most.
  4. Ask for recommendations: This was an idea of another group, a person should be able to ask for recommendations and then maybe again reward the best recommender.

  • Have everything you need close by: paper, scissors, pens, pencils, glue, tape, post-its et cetera
  • If you have redundant elements in your GUI, draw them once and copy them to save time
  • Not every element has to be a replica of the screen. Small elements can just be placed on top of another paper.
  • Take the cover of your smartphone (or make one) and place it on your paper to make it more realistic.

After finishing our first paper prototype we had 3 fellow students test it. The?think aloud method?has proven quite useful to figure out what caused some of our problems.

Here are the problems we discovered with these tests:

  1. Unclear like/dislike buttons for a recommendation
  2. No possibility to comment on a recommendation
  3. Sliders in the “advanced filters” menu are not?recognized?as sliders.

  5. Unclear which fields are required when creating a recommendation
  6. Missing reset filter button (we noticed this ourselves afterwards, it wasn’t needed in the test scenarios)

The modifications we made to the prototype to solve these problems were:

The third session was a testing session!

To evaluate the usability of our application, or at least of our paper prototype, we had to get some feedback from test users.

The most important problems that came forward during the first iteration were the following:

  • It wasn’t immediately clear to the user that the application was meant to share locations with other people.
  • Some users didn’t find the search tab which was located under the ‘explore’ button.
  • On the search tab, the use of the toggle buttons wasn’t clear.

Based on this feedback, we made some changes to our prototype. First of all we rearranged the layout of the ‘recommend’-screen, which we also renamed to ‘recommend location’. We put the ‘location’-field almost at the top of the screen, so the user would definitely notice this. In combination with the name of the tab, ‘recommend location’, it should be more clear that the user should recommend a location and that other information is optional.

We also changed the working of the search-function. After searching, all results are shown now and the toggle buttons can be used as filters, to filter out unwanted results.

After these changes we tested the prototype again on some different test users. The only problems that came up then were related to the fact that it is a?paper prototype and not a digital one. For example, it wasn’t clear that the toggle buttons on the search tab were toggle buttons, which would have been clear on a computer screen.

At last we also noticed that our paper prototype used screens that were bigger than mobile screens. So we drew all screens again, but on a smaller scale and tested the prototype again. The conclusion drawn from these tests, was that the reduced screen-size wasn’t a big issue.

The last part of the session we started on digitizing the prototype.

For building the digital prototype of our application, weu2019re currently exploring different possibilities. Since we are sharing locations and we designed our prototype that way, it will be a mobile application. ?This has an important consequence we must take into consideration:

There is a huge fragmentation of mobile platforms, although there are 2 dominant players: iOS and Android (but Android has many different versions!)

This means if we want to be able to run the app on different platforms, weu2019ll have to write it multiple times. Since thereu2019s no mobile platform middleware as far as we know.

Mobile web applications

The only thing that comes remotely close to having to write the application only once, is writing a mobile web app. In this case our application is some kind of mobile website. By using the new features of HTML5 (e.g. local offline cache, etc.), CSS3 and JavaScript, such an application can approach the behaviour of a local application. Because the application is a web site, you can also run and test it on any pc, which can also be useful.

But of course, not all the mobile browsers implement all the features, so there still might be some minor platform differences to be taken into account.

Tiggzi

To find a solution, we have searched the web a lot and we found the following website: http://www.tiggzi.com. Tiggzi allows you to easily build your mobile application from scratch by dragging the different components to the screen.

Iu2019ve included a preview of a quick draft of our application:

Afterwards, Tiggzi allows you to export the HTML code of your mobile web app, even the platform specific HTML-code as displayed in the following screen shot.

There is unfortunately also a big downside. The free account on Tiggzi only allows applications with up to three pages, which is too small for us. And the cheapest paying subscription is quite expensive (priced at $40 a month). Weu2019ll try to overcome this somewhat, as you can export your code and continue working on it yourself.

Weu2019ll keep you posted, in case we find any other (hopefully free) solutions.

Conclusion

Whether we choose for mobile apps or mobile web apps, there are some trade-offs to be made. Mobile apps definitely have an advantage in speed and features. But mobile web apps can also be used offline and are mostly cross-platform, which is quite an advantage. Also the feature set of new web technologies is ever-increasing.

As some of the comments in our previous post?pointed out, most testers found the ‘advanced filters’-view too overwhelming. In the next iteration of the paper prototype, we’ve addressed this issue. To keep the interface cleaner, we decided to collapse the details of each kind of filter into blocks containing just the title of the filter. When a block is selected it will open, revealing the additional settings. Besides this, we also simplified the filters themselves (being able to specify time frames in minute precision is a bit overkill, filtering by day probably suffices). This results in a easier-to-understand filter system.

A second thing we picked up on from last session, as well as from some blog comments, was that it is a good idea to focus on core functionality first. Later, when the application becomes popular and frequently used, there will be plenty of opportunity to add additional features. This is why we decided not to allow comments for now and to throw out the ‘group’ concept.

Initially, the groups were meant as a communities that could be joined. It would also be possible to send recommendations to whole groups. However, how this joining of groups would work and?who would be able to create these groups still remained unclear. Giving it some thought, it turned out to be too complex. It also wasn’t one of the core-functionalities that we wanted to implement.

Further testing pointed out that the solutions we proposed in our previous post were effective. Also, it didn’t reveal any more problems, so we’ll start work on a first digital prototype!

In this weeks session we tried to evaluate our paper prototype. We did this by asking our fellow students to execute certain tasks on our paper prototype and by asking their feedback after the test. But before we did these tests we actually tried the tests ourself so that the test result could not be biased because of a badly executed test. Did anybody else?actually?do this? When I was the test subject I actually had a feeling in some other groups that there were some disagreements on how certain interactions with the paper prototype had to be done.

Anyway, here is a listing of what we asked of the user:

  • Recommend a new location to Sally.
  • Look at a new incoming interaction.
  • Reply to a new interaction.

Iteration 1

After our first test round which consisted of 4 tests we found the following issues:

Problem 1: Meaning of the arrows on the interaction history is not clear. Some actually thought they were a shortcut button straight to the interaction’s conversation and others did not link it to the incoming and outgoing interaction concept.

Solution1: We made the arrows green and red as people often relate red and green with incoming and outgoing (often indication for calls). We also played with the idea of just using text. Instead of arrows we could use ‘from’ and ‘to’. Green and red are actually not?separable?by some people with color blindness.

Problem 2: This relates to the previous. The filter buttons (arrows) on top of the list was not clear. This could actually be a problem inherent to the paper prototype. Users had trouble seeing them as toggle buttons. But of course toggle buttons are hard to show on a paper prototype as there is not enough feedback available.

Solution 2: As we think this problem arised because of the paper prototype, we did not change it.

Problem 3: ?Login in was not clear for the user without an account. He was not clear how the login would work without a register button.

Solution 3: We are going to make use of Facebook to login and so there will be shown a ‘Facebook connect’ button instead of a custom login form.

Problem 4 : Some feedback we received from one of the test users was that the ‘received’ or ‘sent’ keyword on the interaction detail view was not really integrated in the view itself.

Solution 4: He actually suggested to remove it and replace it by adding ‘from’ and ‘to’ before the interaction names. This created more of a coherent feeling between the interaction overview and the interaction detail view because they both would use the ‘from’ and ‘to’ keyword.

Problem 5: The test user was surprised that new interaction events did not appear at the top of the interaction list.

Solution 5: Sort the interaction list according to latest interaction event date.

Problem 6: The ‘sent arrow’ was not clear in an interaction conversation. People did not see it was actually the button to send it.

Solution 6: We tried to improve the drawing of the arrow.

Problem 7: The magnifying glass to select a contact for sending a new location was not clear. This was because we created a text input field next to the magnifying glass and people tried to click that input field. 2 out of 4 people had this problem.

Solution 7: We removed the input field and made one big button. If the contact is chosen the name appears in the button with the magnifying glass as a logo. The contact can be changed by clicking again on that button.

Problem 8: A taken picture cannot be canceled or changed after the user accepted it.

Solution 8: We changed the picture button with 2 buttons; one to remove it and the other to take a new picture.

Iteration 2

We changed our prototype to these new conclusions and started evaluating the paper prototype a second time.

This time the second goal in our user test was adjusted by asking to filter the evaluation prototype while searching for the new interaction.

This time there were no real problems. But we got some extra feedback which we are going to incorporate?into our digital prototype.

We are going to include an optional share on facebook wall or twitter feed,?add google maps ( or another maps service) to show where a location is and add the?conversation in the detail view. This is something we cannot test on a digital prototype as we need to be able to see how much will fit on a screen. This is why we created a?separate?view for the conversations in our previous iterations.

In our previous blog post, we discussed the more important parts of our paper prototype. Using the think-aloud protocol, we conducted an evaluation with six different users.

These are the most important problems and remarks by our test users:

  • confused by lack of login button;
  • not immediately obvious what the search function does;
  • user doesn’t know if anything happened due to lack of feedback after suggesting or requesting;
  • suggestion type (movie, book, series) shown only when searching, not in activity stream.

In addition there were some minor remarks as well:

  • only one genre can be selected;
  • no clear distinction between the functions of the ‘back’ and ‘cancel’ buttons;
  • function of navigation bar somewhat unclear.

We also asked the opinion of our test users, their thoughts on our app after testing it. These are their general thoughts:

  • clear;
  • quite clear;
  • easy to use;
  • looks nice;
  • bit complex due to similar looking screens;
  • good.

While these thoughts don’t have any explicit value to improve our user interface, implicitly, it serves as a reference to check if we can achieve the goals we have set with our storyboard.

Overall, we think some of the more important issues with our user interface surfaced thanks to these user tests. However, we ask ourselves some questions. Should we blindly adapt our interface to solve any problem encountered by our test users? Are some types of problems found just because our testers are accustomed to programming? How much does the average user care if the functional difference between the back and cancel buttons isn’t clear straight off the bat? If we change the interface to solve some of the problems, does the result reflect the goal we’re trying to reach and can it be identified with our storyboard?

Sure, some of these questions are rhetorical, but we think it’s detrimental to the design process of our user interface to take these into account in order to take the right decisions.

Last week groups were able to test their paper prototypes with other students. We decided to let the first batch of test users do the following three tasks. These tasks were chosen because they represent the most relevant use cases.

  • Search for the frituur in a maximal distance of 3 km and that has the highest rating given by your friends.
  • You ate fries at u2018frituur patjeu2019 and you liked them a lot. Give that frituur a positive rating and recommend it to one of your friends.
  • Try to find whether you have new recommendations.

It didn’t take long for the first usability problems to accumulate. Let us summarize?the issues and how we intend to cope with them below.

1) A recurring problem with rating a frituur came up. You can see in the screen below that a user can give either +1 or -1.

After the user pressed the u2018+1u2019-button, that button would get a green color and the user has to press the rate-button to finalize his review. The problem we identified was that users pressed the u2018+1u2019-button and were waiting for the next screen, without thinking they should press the rate-button at the end.

We asked the test-users about this and they would find it better that the review is finalized immediately after pressing the u2018+1u2019-button. A risk with this approach could be that users accidently press the u2018+1u2019-button and that their rating is not correct. But this scenario can be identified by using u2018Google analyticsu2019 in the digital prototype (for example: if a rating is given within 0.5 seconds by 80% of the users).

2) The screen for u2018mijn aanbevelingenu2019 does not give very much added value since our application will be linked to Facebook. We wanted the user to give a central place to see its recommendations. But we a better approach could be to share your rating with friends on Facebook, by posting a notification on their wall or on your own wall. This has the advantage that friends of your friends can notice the wall-notification and start using our application themselves. The recommendation list will be replaced by a list of the shared ratings your friends did.

It could be in the future that users want an overview of all the recommendations they have done so far. If we feel that the need for this functionality is rising, we can update our application to support this overview (again). But we would like to keep our application as simple as possible.

3) Another issue was the visualization of a rating. We chose to display a rating in two ways: a bar that indicates the percentage of the votes and the amounts of positive and negative votes (as shown in the left part of the image below). The problem is that the percentage bar of a frituur with +5 and -1 ratings has the same length of the bar of a frituur with +300 and -40 ratings. The bar gives no information about the amount of ratings, which could be misleading to the user.

We decided to display the percentage-bar in a different way: by centering the central point of green/red, the user can notice a difference in length. With this approach, we might have to rescale some bars in order to be able to display it within the screen dimensions.

Names are used for easy reference to living beings, objects and non-tangible things. When choosing a name for an application, it shouldn’t be just a name, it has to reflect the function and feeling of the app as well.

A name for an application to allow someone to recommend something to someone else should express its main function, namely the recommending function. Quite some synonyms or closely related words exist for recommend in the context of our application, but it’s necessary to take the connotation into account. We want to choose a name that resonates with the users and expresses the same feeling as our storyboard: the app can be used to recommend things to friends, but those friends shouldn’t be feeling obliged to follow that recommendation.

Force, impose, recommend, advise, suggest,… While any of these words could do the job, we think advise feels less strict, more optional if you wish, than recommend, but it’s easier to pronounce than words like suggest and suggestion.

uAdvise?emphasizes the bifunctional purpose of our app: the u, referring to you, implies the interaction between people, as the app can be used to either give an advice yourself or request?advice from?a friend. In a way, using this name for our application feels like we’re taunting the user in a playful way to use our app: “Why don’t you advise us to watch or read something you like?”

Introduction

This post describes the idea behind the application for the user interfaces course’s project as well as some of its features. The core idea behind the application is to enable users to suggest something to other users.

SuggY

The SuggY application is a mobile application that is used to create recommendations of other mobile apps the user has already installed for other users, i.e. friends in the user profile. As a result, the main entities in the application are the application users and mobile apps. A recommendation can be then understood as a directional relationship between two users with an mobile app as parameter, much like a regular mail message.

The application provides the following functionality:

  • Managing a subset of the other users in a friend list, so-called ‘buddies’, through basic operations such as adding and deleting buddies;
  • Creating new mobile app suggestions, the so-called ‘suggies’;
  • Browsing through sent and received suggies;

Armed with our first design, we asked three people to perform a few tasks on our paper prototype. The first task was to recommend a steakhouse in Leuven to Carl using a picture. For the second task, the user had to search recommendations of concerts at his current location with the highest rating, recommended by a friend. These tests resulted in the following remarks and solutions, listed by descending importance:

  1. The function of the? “What are friends recommending”-button was confusing and had some overlap with both the Share and Ask functionality. Our first solution for this problem was a refactoring of the name to “Recommendations by friends” which showed both recommendations by friends and recommendations directed to the user, but with a clear separation. However, this solution imposed a problem when the user did not have any recommendations by friends yet. Therefore we renamed the button to “Recent recommendations” which shows a complete feed along with a few filters and sorting options.
  2. The users expected an auto-complete feature for the “To” field in the Share screen which showed the available contains. This auto-complete features is now implemented to show the user’s contacts in alphabetical order along with an option to share with everyone.
  3. The “What” field and the “Keywords” field made the users unsure on where to put which information while sharing. Two possible options were to drop the “Keywords” field or to only display it when relevant, based on what the user entered in the “What” field. We decided to simply drop the field and implement the second option if further tests demanded this.
  4. The result list did not show enough information about each result. We therefore decided to show more information like the location, recommender, the date of recommendation and the rating.
  5. Finally, the text of the share confirmation popup, “Are you sure?” was too confusing. It was not clear that this popup came from the Share button. Therefore we changed the text to “Share now?”.

The result of these changes will be revealed in our next post.
We proudly present you the second version of our paper prototype:

Similar to the first iteration, we gathered a group of volunteers to test the second version of our paper prototype. To check whether the solutions of the first iteration eliminated the problems, we used the same tests as in iteration one. As we hoped, the remarks from the first iteration were not mentioned this time. Apart from a few minor remarks, no new problems arose. We therefore decided that the paper prototype has been sufficiently tested and it is time to start working on the actual digital prototype.

We said it before and we’ll say it again: paper prototypes are useful. Some of the more important benefits of creating paper prototypes are:

  • no time is wasted with programming to conclude a certain design doesn’t work;
  • way quicker than using a digital prototype;
  • (quite) easy to change something when using paper;
  • it hurts less to start from scratch when not pleased with an interface design.

Like with all things, paper prototypes have some negative aspects as well:

  • no exact representation of the design as it would look on the device it’s developed for, i.e. size of buttons, icons,… differs from its digital counterpart;
  • it takes a bit more time to draw if icons are to be used;
  • specific gestures like scrolling can’t be reproduced accurately using a paper prototype;
  • it looks bland, it isn’t immediately obvious if elements are clickable or not and whether some elements are buttons or not.

To us, the pros outweigh the cons of using a paper protype, but serious caution is needed when using this paper prototype to conduct tests. That’s where things could potentially get ugly. A delicate balance needs to be found between creating a simple prototype and adding enough details to simulate a realistic feeling. Providing too much detail in a paper prototype would nullify its goal to minimize initial design time. Not enough detail leads to an unrepresentative look and feel of the user interface. That’s why it’s not necessarily a bad thing to ignore remarks and comments on things like scrolling, the colours used, etc to a certain degree, without becoming completely ignorant about major design flaws.

The sooner the switch is made from paper prototyping to a digital version, the better, but only after the main problems with the paper prototype are solved. Minor problems can easily be addressed during a next stage of the design process and, depending on the kind of problems, will even solve themselves if the interface is tested on the device it’s developed for, as there’s only so much one can achieve using a paper prototype.

The fourth session was mainly composed about documenting the tests with did with our paper prototype the session before.

Professor Duval indicated it was very important to these test with much detail. This way we could make it clear to the reader of this documentation what we saw during these tests, what we concluded from these results and which changes we made to our application in light of these conclusions.

For the tests in each iteration, there are five steps:

  • the goal of the test
  • the ?testing method we applied
  • why we used a certain method
  • who was tested and where
  • the bare results (no interpretation) of the tests
  • finally which problems were discovered by analyzing the results.

Furthermore, at the beginning of each iteration it is important to indicate which problems we will address in that iteration, the possible alternatives that can be a solution for the problems and finally which of these solutions we choose and why for each problem.

The problems that come forward when testing our paper prototype can be read in a previous?blog post. There are also some solutions suggested in this post.

At the end of the session we also designed the test for our first digital prototype. We will use 2 type of tests. First, we will let the user think-aloud when executing tasks and we will count the number of clicks that is necessary to finish each task in a correct way. Secondly, we will time some other test users to get some measures of how much time the different tasks we propose take.

The results of these tests will, on one hand, let us make new changes in the user interface if people still have interface-related problems with the different tasks.

On the other hand, the efficiency test (counting the clicks and timing) will give us information about how much effort the users need to do for completing each task. If this is to high for most users, we will need to rethink the design, so we can reduce the needed effort.

During the two weeks, in which there will be no session, we will find as much test users as possible, so the conclusions we get of these tests are real problems for most users and not just outliers.

Iteration goal

Test the general usability of the paper?prototype.

Method

We used the think-aloud protocol.

Tasks for our test users:

  • make a suggestion;
  • make a request;
  • reply on a received request.

Rationale

Another option was to?show the test users our prototype and let them fill in a questionnaire, but this requires?more preparation?time and one of the advantages of the think-aloud protocol is that it’s a fast way to obtain a lot of information. Also, execution speed of the tasks is?less important: making use of a paper prototype doesn’t result in accurate and representative timings of?a given set of?tasks.

Who, where, when

We tested 6 fellow?students (master computer science), at?200B?00.16, Celestijnenlaan?200, 3001 Heverlee, between the hours of 3 PM and 7 PM, on Tuesday, March 5th. Each user evaluation took no less than 2 minutes?and no more than?6 minutes.

Results

  1. One?person expressed his confusion about the lack of a login button, while the other test persons hesitated for a few seconds before proceeding.
  2. The emptiness of the search screen came as a surprise to?one person and made him hesitate. It was indicated by two other test subjects that it was confusing that you had to search for an item to suggest.
  3. Two test subjects mentioned that the lack of feedback after suggesting or requesting was a problem.
  4. One person requested for a visual indicator of the suggestion type in the activity stream (as there is?at the search screen).
  5. Half of our test subjects wanted to select more than one genre while creating a request.
  6. One person said that the difference between the functions of the ‘back’ and ‘cancel’ buttons was unclear.
  7. One subject mentioned that the navigation bar in the main screen was useless, since it only contained a settings button.

Conclusions

We received what we’d?like to divide in?two types of critiques: high-priority and low-priority. Most of the lower-priority comments might be related to the fact that it is a paper prototype we are testing, so we will postpone this until the digital prototype. These are 6 and?7 (see results). Comment 5 was misinterpreted, we saw it as an inclusive selection, while the test subjects thought of it as an exclusive selection of multiple genres. The remaining comments are of higher-priority and will be addressed before the digital prototype is tested.
